summary: This is a letter from the French Ministry of Justice to the U.S. Department of Justice, transmitted via the U.S. Embassy in Paris, explaining French extradition law. It states that France cannot extradite French nationals, and that nationality is assessed at the time of the alleged offense, with subsequent loss of nationality being irrelevant to extradition.

persons.name: Amirew Finkelwan
persons.context: Serves as the liaison magistrate at the U.S. Embassy in Paris, acting as the intermediary for transmitting this legal communication from the French Ministry of Justice to the U.S. Department of Justice.

events.title: French Ministry Issues Extradition Clarification
events.description: The French Ministry of Justice sends a letter to the U.S. Department of Justice, via the U.S. Embassy, outlining the legal principles governing extradition from France, specifically the prohibition on extraditing French nationals.

keyFacts: French law, specifically Articles 696 et seq. of the Code of Criminal Procedure, governs extradition procedures.
France cannot extradite any person who has French nationality.
The critical time for assessing nationality is the time of the alleged offense; loss of French nationality after the offense does not make extradition possible.
The letter is a formal response or clarification from French authorities to a U.S. extradition request, likely related to a French national sought in the Epstein case.
